Building problems delay
co-op opening to October 1
By SUE WOOLHISER
Residents of Rogers House,
placed in temporary housing due
to construction delays in the
renovation of the building can
expect the new Co-op to be
completed by Oct. 1.
During the last week in August
the 24 female residents were
informed they would be placed
in neighboring apartments on a
temporary basis for the month of
Sept.
"Our plans are to have people
in by Oct.1," said Peter Heist,
Director of Housing, "According
to both the contractor and the
University it will be ready." He
attributed the delay to
unexpected construction
problems that required city
, building inspectors to approve
the renovation before the
workmen could continue. "It was
a matter of meeting the codes,"
he added, "It was a legitimate
delay."
Students generally have been
tolerant but not pleased about
the delay. "It's an annoying
inconvenience," said one of the
future Rogers' tenants. "It could
be worse," said another woman,
"Of course I would rather be at
Rogers House." The students

seemed placated by the fact that
the University said it will provide
movers when Rogers House is
completed.
"I'm overwhelmed at the
positive response by the
students," said Heist, "There
have been no major complaints
,so far." According to Heist only
one woman complained about
being housed in a double room
when she had contracted for a
single. Two others refused the
temporary housing and stayed in
private housing in order to
!eliminate moving twice.
"I'm expecting it to be done,"
said Heist, "It is too early to be
negative. Nothing but the
'positive can be expressed."
Heist noted the city officials
had been very cooperative in
,spite of the building problems,
and that the contracter has been
going out of his way to get it
done as soon as possible. The
University also has a
representative who checks on the
building progress daily. One
workman said, "It'll definitely be
done in a month."
The Housing office estimated
the basic rebuilding should be
done around the 20th to 23rd of
Sept. allowing time for the

University to prepare the interior
furnishings.
Presently the women are
housed in furnished apartments
at the Carlisle House, The
Marylander, or in University
owned row houses.
In mid-August the Housing
office determined Rogers House
would not be ready for Sept. and
sought housing in the area,
contacting approximately 25-30
places.

Homewood Vice President
George Benton has cited plans to

new Dean of Students Robert

claled for representation from

organization that will encompass

been notified by the Vice

Bureaucratic inefficiency and red tape are
institutional viruses just as common at Hopkins as at
any federal agency. Yet there is no excuse for tuition
bills mailed to students less than one month before
they return, first thing, to register. Such negligence
irritates students forced to wait two hours in a line for
a "permit to register" only to discover the Office of
the Controller has not yet cleared payment with the
Registrar. "Come back tomorrow," pleads the irritated
secretary for the fiftieth time.
There is no reason to suspect a conspiracy involving
the Controller and the Registrar to deliberately stall
the registration process. After all, just imagine the
interest the University could collect on an extra two
months from S 5,400,000!
Two days is not long enough to register 2000
students with little or no waiting. There are other
alternatives available and worthy of exploration.
Registration by mail during the summer, or a post
spring term registration on campus are two. The
former is used with success at many colleges and
universities nationwide.
